WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs Helen Martin
Address Gray Lake
Birthplace Cable Illinois

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? March 1929.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Cass 33 - 14 - 17.
Where had you been living before that? Not sure of all 44 3 or 4.
For how many people did you prepare meals? ........................................
How far was it to your nearest store? 11 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Coffee tea sugar flour navy beans rice canned tomatoes

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood.

In what quantities did you buy it? 10 pounds at a time.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Around $3.00.
How much did you use Graham flour? Once a week.
Whole wheat flour? With white flour once a week.
Was flour milled locally? No. How far away? 60 miles. What year? 1919-1910.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 85 cents to 1.75.
What other grain products did you use? ..................................................
Cornmeal? Corn meal. Whole wheat? Farina? ........................................
Other? ................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes.
How did you grind it? With a little hand mill we used to grind grain for chickens.
1929. Martin, Mrs. Helen Gray.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 400 to 600 lbs at a time.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50 to $2.00 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Crown Brand.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 gallon.

At what price? From $7.50 to $9.00 cents per gal.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had a cow and shipped from there.

Butter? Made our butter. Used chickens for eggs.

What was the price of butter? Didn't buy. Butter or eggs?

Did you pick eggs for winter? Yes, home cooked them.

Did you make butter? Yes, cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cream, cheddar.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork and beef, fish, chicken.

How did you get fresh meat? Farmed beef, in winter for summer use.

How often did you get fresh meat? Once a week in summer.

How did you preserve meat? Making a brine of salt, bath salts, brown sugar for pork.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized? No.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? No.

For how long? No.

What part did fish play in the family diet? In the winter we would get frozen white fish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Frozen, canned fish.

Kinds? Salmon and white fish.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black Robin. At what price? $0.45 per pound.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Regular. Price? $1.50 per pound.

What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $1.25 per bushel.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? From the market.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1918, Cabbage 1919, Carrots 1919, Onions 1919,

Turnips 1919, Beets 1919.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 4 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box.

What weight? 15 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? In bulk or by the box.

What was the price of prunes?

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? Figs.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas? No, corn? No, beans? No, Saskatoons? No, other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1919.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1919.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1919.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning while I lived on the farm I preserved.

To what extent? And canned fruit and meat every year.

Did you make your own vinegar? Some times.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought some and made some.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Brown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood and coal.

Where did you get your fuel? Coal at home, wood about 42 miles north of our home.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? Bought in M.D.P.

That year was it purchased? 1924. Price? $45.00

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron and tin and enamel

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? About 1910

Aluminum? 1910-1911

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Turkey dressing pickle Potatoes home made Bread
